flashcards.english: Drinks: Njoohi (beer), Maai (water), Maai ma macungwa (orange juice), Iria (milk), Iria igagatu (fermented milk), Ũcũrũ mũgagatu (fermented porridge), Thoota (soda). Foods: Mũkimo (mashed food), Cabaci (chapattis), Mũgate (bread), Mũcere (rice), Mboco (beans), Nyama (meat), Thamaki/Kĩũngũyũ (fish), Mũtura (traditional sausage). Cooking verbs: Gũkaranga (to fry), Gũtherukia (to boil), Kũhĩhia (to roast), Gũkanda mũtu (to make dough)
flashcards.notes: Comprehensive food, drinks, and cooking vocabulary. Note: Kĩũngũyũ is original Kikuyu word for fish, Thamaki is borrowed. Fermented drinks (igagatu) are traditional

flashcards.english: Wambũi mĩcore (zebra), Mũrũthi (lion), Ndũiga (giraffe), Huria (rhinoceros), Njogu (elephant), Mbogo (buffalo)
flashcards.notes: Iconic safari animals. Wambũi mĩcore literally describes zebra's striped pattern

flashcards.english: Gũtũnda (to have a rash), Ndĩ mũtũndu guoko (I have a rash on my arm), Thundo (pimple/s), Ndĩna thundo ũthiũ (I have a pimple on my face), Kĩronda (a wound), E na kironda iru (he/she has a wound on his knee), Kũrwara (to be sick), Ndĩ mũrwaru nda (I am sick in the stomach), Gũturwo (to have pain)
flashcards.notes: Health and medical conditions. Pattern: Ndĩ mũrwaru + body part for location of illness. Kĩronda (wound) uses class agreement

flashcards.english: Igokora/Kĩgokora (elbow - variant pronunciations), Rucuĩrĩ (single hair strand), Njuĩrĩ (hair - collective, no matter how many strands)
flashcards.notes: Additional body parts. Note singular/collective distinction: Rucuĩrĩ (one strand) vs Njuĩrĩ (hair in general). Regional variation: Igokora/Kĩgokora both acceptable

flashcards.english: Kĩongo/Ciongo (head), Njuĩrĩ/Njuĩrĩ (hair - invariant), Gũtũ/Matũ (ear), Ũthĩĩ/Maũthĩĩ (face), Inĩũrũ/Manĩũrũ (nose), Rũrĩmĩ/Nĩmĩ (tongue), Rĩĩtho/Maĩtho (eye), Guoko/Moko (hand), Kĩara/Ciara (finger), Igokora/Magokora (elbow), Kũgũrũ/Magũrũ (leg), Iru/Maru (knee)
flashcards.notes: Complete body parts with singular/plural forms showing noun class patterns. Ma- is common plural prefix for body parts. Includes trilingual comparison (English/Swahili/Kikuyu)
